The sun is gliding the luxurious blue</br>Of the clear morning heav'ns — the dark leaf'd lime,</br>The date, the palm, and branch of ev'ry hue</br>Fruit-hung or bloss'ming in the fragrant clime;</br>Above, the day is gleaming broad and high—</br>Beneath, the ruins of lost Carthage lie—

The palaces — adorned capitals—</br>The golden lined temples — each high fane—</br>The deities of gold — majestic halls—</br>Throng'd sounding streets; — and does then nought remain</br>Of all the wealth, vain mistress of the sea,</br>Save these few stones to tell the history?

Where are the young and brave — the ag'd and proud—</br>The pow'rless and the mighty — where the fair?</br>The cypress zon'd and the noble brown'd,</br>Whose lips were murm'ring on the summer air?</br>I ask'd the skies what ravager had come—</br>The silent earth? — the skies and earth were dumb!

The lover moans his tale of griefs — and dies;</br>The warrior finds his death on the battle-field;</br>A kingdom as a village wasted lies—</br>A monarch as a slave — alike all yield:</br>The pompous monument denies at last</br>Its feeble voice — that falls — is with the past.

Say what art thou — thus terrible in might,</br>Who giv'st the young heart bitterness and tears;</br>Destroying nations in thy clam'rous flight,</br>Humbling the pride of youth, the strength of years?</br>Say what art thou — whose voice was with the birth</br>Of the new world — and cursed the infant earth?

The streams flow'd by in loveliness and song,</br>The flow'rs sprang joyous into radiant life,</br>The beautiful of air and earth, among</br>The woods rose up — the fields in sweets lay rife—</br>A paradise where angels might have ranged;</br>Thou cam'st — earth trembled — the new world was chang'd!</br>
